title: Hungaryball
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
RIA RIA HUNGÁRIA!

During these weeks the the 2017 Fina World Championship takes place in my city, Budapest. On this occasion I've decided to finish my long planned Hungary countryball collection and share them with you. This little guy is the first one in the series. Two more are coming soon...

He is a cheerful, active, little countryball, who will happily pose with you on your photos when you're roaming around the city with your friends or wandering on the beautiful countryside of Hungary.

EDIT (2017.10.12.): Updated the model, so now it has the same 22 mm distance between the clips as the Betyár countryball, in case you would like to combine the two into an only mustache/only hat countryball.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This model is designed to be printed in multiple parts, WITHOUT support. Since the eyes are separate pieces you can print the tree layers in the colors of your country's flag. For the best accuracy print it slow! I've used 20 mm/s for the outer walls. Print two of the clips.

Assembly

The model is designd to be assembled without glue only with its snap-fit joints. Use the exploded view as a guide. First attach the tree layers with the clips, then push the eyes with the contours in their place.

Note that the tolerances were designed to fit the accuracy of my Ultimaker 2. You will need a similarly accurate printer and fine settings for the snap-fit joints to work properly, otherwise you might have to readjust the size of the clips.

description.text:
A customizer friendly slope test generator file.

Use this file to determine how much edge you can handle at specific settings on your printer.

Here is how I use it. When I have a long running print to do that has overhangs, I will decide what quality/temp/etc I am using for the print. I will then load this file up and run various slopes to determine where I really need and do not need support structures.

I print this with no support, no raft, as is at whatever settings my up-coming print will be. This way, I can see what both positive and negative slopes will look like.

Customizer makes it easy to change the number of test slopes and angles. I would not shrink the height to ensure there is enough slope to see any defects which may show up.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

10%

Notes:

The settings above are not what you should use specifically. This should be printed just before a long running print so you can judge where supports are needed to assist your overhangs.

Examine the positive slopes to make sure they are even. If they are not even, then you may want to adjust your settings.

Examine the negative slopes for drooping or warping. Either can be caused from a variety of issues, but since we are testing our settings, which is a good sign that you will need supports to assist on those slopes.

The hammer nuts should be the right size to simply screw an M3 screw right in, no need to tap the threads.

Download, print, install. Easy as pie.
To hold the controller case to the mounting plate use two M3 countersunk screws, don't forget to put the nuts in place inside the case before you mount the controller inside.

3 top solid layers, 4 shells/parameters, 7 solid bottom layers (to lower center of mass), 20 skirt outlines with 0.0mm offset, 0.50mm extrusion width, retraction enabled, nozzle wipe disabled.

70mm/s print speed, 70% first layer, 75% outer parameter speed, 85% solid infill speed, 200mm/s x/y axis movement speed.

Nozzle temp @ 225c, bed temp @ 70c

This models was designed with our help by a six-years-old child .
We help our students to learn 3D computer design using Blender. While designing this pieces a student needed to figure out which components of lego bricks are crucial to make pieces to connect to each other, and which are not very important; how many pieces of each brick he needed for building his model, and which pieces he can substitute with others.

title: Camera Quick Release Clamp/Tripod mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here is a quick release clamp and plate for DSLRs and other cameras. Made this because I needed a larger number of these that are compatible with other release plates. Bigger than these usually are (88x70x25mm) for stability. I printed this in Carbonfiber PETG at 0.150 mm resolution 5 perimeters top and bottom layers with 50% infill. Near indestructible.The 3/8-16, 1/4-20 and M6 threads may need to be cut again depending on how you print this. You also need two 25-30mm long springs from regular pens, an M6 50mm screw and M6 washer and nut that should snap into the knob. For the bracket you need a 1/4-20 camera equipment screw. Screw in the M6 screw tightly, it should not move when turning the knob. You may have to lubricate the nut. Make sure the knob fits into the back part I widened the opening for it a little more. Updated the front part to fit more camera plates with screws in the bottom and the ANSI screw threads for better printing and compatibility.

L-bracket www.thingiverse.com/thing:2439918 will also fit.

title: Vertical Z ( 4th ) Axis Gimbal Stabilizer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE!

This design has been superseded (twice) by my new Pro 2 Model 4th Axis Stabilizer which produces at least 50% smoother footage.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2689804

There's also a similarly smooth Compact Pro version made for phone and action cam gimbals here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2689804

Here's a design for all you amateur and professional videographers out there!

The handheld gimbal stabilizer has been one of the most significant game changers for independent filmmakers allowing professional results whilst removing the need for tens of thousands of dollars worth of equipment.

But they still lack one vital ingredient, they don’t stabilize for up and down motion and rely on the filmmakers skill to minimise this motion with their arm.

This up and down vertical motion or Z ( or 4th ) axis motion isn’t always possible to reduce by hand especially with fast action or walking backwards.

That’s when I decided to build a Z axis stabilizer for handheld gimbals and after a number of design iterations I’m really happy with my Z Axis Gimbal Stabilizer with Fluid Dampening. It takes Gimbal cinematography to that next level!

Check out the showcase video here:- https://youtu.be/xOCkKlXSjO8

Check out the Assembly video here:- https://youtu.be/6a4sg2BikhE

################## UPDATE: ###################

1) There was an typo in one of the springs. Fortunately it's the spring less people would be using but I've updated the correct one in the post printing section. Sorry!
2) There's also an additional support added that's for larger or non symmetrical gimbal handles. It's called ZAS_holderFlat.stl
3) I've also given some more advice in the post printing section about setting up the fluid dampening that isn't covered in the DIY video.

Note:This Z axis stabilizer will handle light to heavy rigs. The only thing you need to change is the springs - Links to springs are in the 'Post Printing' section.

The full list of parts is found in the Post Printing section below.

You can check out my other designs here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/ScottyMakesStuff/designs

You can see all my videos on my YouTube Channel, ScottyMakesStuff here:-
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UChDeVchB6CCF--0wQQYNIhQ
https://twitter.com/ScottyMakesStuf
https://www.instagram.com/scottymakesstuff/

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

15

Notes:

Most pieces were printed in PLA with 3 perimeters and with supports. Since the holder takes the most stress I'd suggest 4 perimeters and 25% fill.

There's 3 different central gimbal holders in the file. These 3 are sized for gimbals with the sized handle diameter as follows;- under 28mm (1 in), under 34mm(1 1/3 in) [fits my Zhiyun Crane], under 40mm (1.58 in). (If your gimbal can't fit any of these then you can use the ZAS_holderFlat.stl)

I've only included one side of the arms and handles so you'll need to mirror a copy of each of these for the full set.
The Fluid Dampening insert will need a total of 4 printed and the knobs need 2.

I now mainly use Simplyfy3D to slice for three main reasons;-

  1. the supports come away beautifully and
  2. for items that rely on tight tolerances it prints the most accurate that I've used and
  3. You can specify different print settings in a print so for sections with detail you can reduce layer height and for uniform sections you can increase it and get great looking prints done fast!

I suggest printing this in an improved PLA (see below) or other filament that's strong and tough.

Beware: Not all PLA's are made equal.

Most of my prototypes and a good proportion of final prints are with an 'improved' PLA from Esun called PLA Plus (sometimes called pro) and it's tough and definitely not brittle and it's really cheap too. Some other moderately priced improved PLA's I've used are Filamentum, Prusa Brand & Colorfabb Economy PLA.

I haven't tried Hatchbox Pro PLA, Matterhackers, Taulman InPLA and Filaform Pro PLA but I hear some good things about them.

I also use a few better quality name brand PLA's for special one off jobs and these are quite a bit better than the Esun though up to triple the price.

For the best looking prints with a fair bit better toughness than the Esun I use either Polymaker PolyMax PLA or ColorFabb PLA PHA. If excellent toughness and strength is a priority then the Polymaker PC Max polycarbonate is the one I'll always reach for and the finish is still good too.

List of non-printing parts
  • 10 x 1/4 in by 60mm (2.36 in) fully threaded mushroom head bolts
  • 1 x 1/4 in by 25mm (1 in) fully threaded mushroom or round head bolts for upright gimbal screw
  • 1 x 1/4 in by 35mm (1.38 in) fully threaded mushroom or round head bolts for inverted gimbal screw
  • 10 x 1/4 in nuts - I suggest you use nylock nuts or loctite for 8 of the 10 nuts as these can work loose.
  • 2 x 1/4 in wingnuts
  • 2 x extension springs -
    • For Camera/Gimbal weight of 1.3kg to 3Kg use http://www.centuryspring.com/extension-spring-651.html
    • For Camera/Gimbal weight of 800gm to 1.2Kg use http://www.centuryspring.com/extension-spring-642.html
    • For very light rigs (under 800 grams) like the Feiyu G4 Plus & iPhone you could trial lighter springs as I'm sure there's a spring that will work. Otherwise, next week I'm coming up with a single handed version that will use the same support arms and fluid dampening but have a purpose built handle and gimbal holder
  • Tube of thick grease - (see DIY video)
  • two part epoxy glue (Araldite)

################## Note: #####################

The following applies more so with lighter payloads but it's good advice for everyone setting up their fluid dampening:-
I'd suggest trialling using only 2 of the fluid dampening modules filled with grease at first and leaving the other two modules in dry (i.e. in both handles have one greased and the other dry). There's a certain amount of resistance with the fluid dampening to stop the bounce and under a lighter payloads you might find it too much dampening meaning that light movements won't get stabilized enough. If the bounce reduction is to your liking with half the dampening then stick with that.

comments.author: ScottyMakesStuff

comments.text:
I'd still lean towards the lighter spring as that's right in the middle of it's performance zone. Though you're right that ballast will improve things. It adds inertia which is what keeps the gimbal from bouncing about. You'd probably need to add at least 300g of ballast to use the heavier spring though. I noticed you're in Oz so both of those Century springs are available at Bunnings - C-181 is the heavier one and the other is C-143.
I use 6 single thin brass washers between the moving plastic parts as there's a small amount of friction where the plastic touches plastic. This of course will be reduced by using nylock nuts that aren't cranked down too far. I made sure there was still a fraction of a millimetre of play.
The grease is just bog standard lithium grease. You could use a more expensive grease with viscosity that isn't affected by changes in ambient temps but that's probably overkill. In the notes I mention on lighter rigs to trial filling just one of the two fluid dampening modules in each handle with grease at first as that may give enough dampening.

title: AAXA P300 Pico Projector Fan Adapter

description.text:
This is a parametric fan adapter for a particular pico projector that has a noisy-ass fan. This adapter allows you to remove the factory fan and instead attach a silent fan to the outside of the projector housing.

The included 30mm fan operates at 9000rpm and makes a really obnoxious (decibel level aside) sound. I replaced this with a 92mm 2000rpm* fan that is practically silent when used with this adapter. With the adapter the perceptible projector sound is now some sort of switching noise coming from within the light engine itself. Don't think I'm going to 3d print my way out of that :)

I experimented with the hull extrusion height as low as 10mm and it seemed adequate but the exhaust airflow out of the front of the unit was perceptibly less than the factory solution. A 20mm hull extrusion height seems to yield similar exhause airflow with the 92mmm 2000rpm fan I selected (Real science, I know).

  • Note if you pick a lower RPM fan you've got to design a RPM signal generator or else the projector will shut down after several seconds. I used a 555 Timer with 1 uF capacitor and 5kOhm potentiometer. Will attach that circuit schematic later...

author: haywardismyfault

title: LaunchPad with Rockets and a Plane

author: D3C0Y

title: Ord Bot Z-Axis Conversion to Belt Drive

description.text:
I had problems with my ord bot lead screws causing my motors to grind and get out of sync. I had experience with a belt drive delta bot so I wanted to make the switch to make my z-axis belt drive. It's working pretty smooth. The only real drawback is that the gantry will fall once the motors are un-powered so I still need to design flip out rest for it at the top. I've posted the stl files as well as the scad files. My motors actually atach to aluminum angle with holes meant for the original setup. The belt clamp should bolt right to a z-lift block hole. You might need to drill the other one out though from the gantry plate. Let me know if you have any questions! Advantages of belt driven Z-axis:
Fast response for max z endstop homing
Better suited for autoleveling (in my opinion)
Zero z-wobble
No need for lubrication and less noise as a result. I have posted a couple images of a 20 hr print of a large football helmet that demonstrates good looking layers at 0.2 mm layer height. **Update: Added a mashup of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:43069 with my current motor bracket so it will work with misumi, as recommended by blah_59. Here's videos of the first tests and printing:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OvG_cZWBxVk
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z6Kx2tsMY4I
http://youtu.be/4NoBIgc69HM **Make sure to hook up z-axis motors separatley and reversed. I hooked them both up in the same direction and fried a driver due to the motors working against each other!*** Update-03/10/14: I have now implemented a counter balance pulley system using 2 lbs of lead sinkers and 30 lb test fishing line. I've posted the updated files. Credit goes to whosawhatsis http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3970 for the printed idler pulleys.

There are two versions of the motor bracket and two versions of the idler bracket. The one version of the motor bracket will work on the misumi which is found on most ord bots. The gantrys on other ord bots might stick out farther so there is a standard and extended version of the idler. What's needed: 4-6 x 4mmx8mm screws for idler brackets
4-6 x 4mm T slot nuts
6 x 4mm washers
2 x 4mm x 40 mm screws
4 x 624zz bearings (only two would be needed if you using printed pulleys
2 x 6mm GT2 belt
2 x GT2 20 tooth pulleys
4 x 1/8" or 3mm rods for locking belt loops in clamp
4 x 5mmx12mm screws
4 x 5mm nuts (could add two more to gantry plates for strength
8x3mm screws for motors
mounting screws for motor brackets to frame

comments.text:
I have been thinking of going that way for my new printer, do you have more insights to share? any other things to know / watch for using belts for the Z axis?
Also could you post some new pictures or video of the counter weight / balance system?
Thanks.
comments.author: thecrazy

comments.text:
Thank you! I do have some tips to offer. I love belts and could never do the screws. The main thing with belts are that your pulley brackets need to be sturdy. Often times the belts aren't stretching, the brackets are bending. This can affect the layers. Ideally they'd be metal, but it's easier to print them. Mine actually flex a little, but work well. Also, you want your pulley to carriage connections to be optimized so that the maximum amount of the pulley teeth are gripping the belt. I had found my right belt wasn't gripping the best and had to modify the bracket.
I'm actually designing my own printer that's also going to be completely belt driven, then I may put this one up for sale after the new printer's built. I'll try to get some more pictures and video posted of the pulley system.

title: Customizable Rocker Switch Panel (attaches to boards, like i3)

description.text: 3/7/14: Updated to support angles 90-180. Thanks MyMakibox. (Previously 94 downloads.) I found a bunch of these rocker switches on ebay only a few dollars, so for this printer, I'm forgoing my cool fully printable switch panel (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30348), and using these things instead. This is fully customizable (rows, columns, angle, etc) if you open in customizer. You just snap the switch into place and wire it up. Be careful that you leave enough room for your nuts to fit on the backs of the angled extenders -- I need to add some code that looks out for that case, but it's not in there yet. You might notice that I I actually use M2 hardware so I didn't have to have the nut on the front. The clip, by the way, is the same one I use in my other designs, like the Test Tube Holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:240275). You can insert a nut into the trap, and use a set screw to tighten it down to the board. You might not even have to do that, though. Switches: Last I checked, you can still get 20 switches for $3.14, shipping included on ebay. Search "20 Pcs Boat Rocker Switch"

title: Temporary Outside Faucet Vacuum Breaker Cap

description.text:
Outside faucet vacuum breaker cap. Apparently, these aren't normally sold alone in Lowe's. This is where 3d printing /really/ came in handy (details below).

NOTE: THIS IS TEMPORARY! You should get a real replacement of a vacuum breaker since this is only a cap.

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=193647

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Play

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Printed slow (4000 mm/min) for quality. Note that, for me, 0.10 resolution caused microholes in the whole part which let the water spurt through. 0.15 fixed that.

I also added an extra outside solid layer all around (4 instead of 3) - but probably doesn't make a difference.

Although I could have 3d printed it myself, my family isn't ready for that as a first-option. I went to Lowe's and they didn't have this part - only the whole $50 faucet replacement with a pipe going long into the wall. If I did it, it would be a guaranteed leak. And a plumber's cost would otherwise pay the printer. Happy to pay it if needed, but not for a 10 cent part! Plus, we needed it that /very/ day, so 1-no-amazon, and 2-emergency-plumber fees.

Took 10 iterations to get the threading, size, infill, height, etc, /just/ right, but it works perfectly. With the rubber washer insert, no leaks, no spurts. I made it orange to make it obvious it was 3d printed. I'm sure I'll get a request someday to change the color :)

Robot educativo DYOR para primaria y secundaria de bajo coste para iniciarse en la robòtica. Es de fácil construcción y permite gran variedad de experimentos como evitar obstáculos,melodías,siguelíneas,pantalla leds y bluetooth para controlarlo remotamente
Muy fácil de decorar con goma eva u otros materiales

Tinkercad (diseño del robot y piezas) ,Inkscape (plantilla corte con laser ), Fritzing ( conexiones electrónicas), Facilino 1.0.1 (compatible arduino) y App inventor 2 Hardware:
Chasis de madera de 150mmx150mm
Electrónica: Arduino nano v3.0(compatible), extensión arduino nano, sensor ultrasonidos(HC-SR04),zumbador KY-006, matrix de leds 8x8 max7219,spp-c bluetooth(compatible HC-06), siguilíneas TCRT-5000,2 microservos de rotación continua con ruedas FS-90R , 2 microservos SG-90, rueda loca y bateria Powerbank 2000 mAh.

VIDEOS Enlace 1 youtube https://youtu.be/QfhMafsBTd4 .Muestro al robot controlado con la interfaz desarrollado con app inventor 2. Control de expresiones y movimientos básicos
Enlace 2 youtube https://youtu.be/e2l5HL0mZSs .Muestro al robot de forma autónoma.Evita obstáculos. Si los encuentra se enfada,pita y da vueltas y si no está feliz

Chasis del robot es de madera cortado con láser.
Decoración realizada con goma eva (ver fotos). Se necesita pegamento de barra o cola blanca.La goma eva es un material adecuado para ñiños de primaria ya que pueden personalizar el robot facilmente.Además permite volver a reutilizarlo en otros proyectos

description.text:
Work needed some cord guards to ensure that copiers couldn't be unplugged from power conditioners in various client locations. I looked at the general shape of other cord guards and did not reinvent the wheel.

I made it so that each end will hold a zip tie. It is parameterized so that it can easily be resized in all dimensions. I added a spline to one side so that they would fit together and reinforce each other. Tape could be wound around the device or it could be glued along the spline.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

20%

Notes:

On octopi I lay it down on its open side, then click lay flat and it turns it up at an angle with the spline lower than the other side. If it turns it up the other way, just make it -42 instead of 42 and it should orient it the right way.

Once it is laying in a printable way, duplicate it. Print it. Remove supports. Rotate the two halves and fit them around the cord. Zip tie and glue for a permanent install.

description.text:
MendelMax and Aluminum Extrusions are awesome to work with. This Y-rod holder is inspired by the ziptie-less LM8UU holders by Jonas Kuehling while also being compatible with MendelMax.
MendelMax v1 had Y-rod holders that spanned two extrusions. v1.5 has a lasercut piece to attach to the center of one extrusion. I like this design but I wanted more play in the length of y-rods that could be used (so I could recycle some from previous bots) and also I wanted a 3D printable version because I can't use wood in my designs (for bioengineering stuff).
Designed in Blender because my OpenSCAD-fu is not very good. .blend file is attached.

You need 2 holders per 3D printer. I use the 4off file because I like to have backups and am building more than one printer :D
These are 10 mm thick, so use M5x16 mm screws to attach to the 2020 Aluminum extrusion instead of the standard M5x10 mm screws. I also print these at 80% infill to make sure they are super rigid. You don't want anything bending or slipping, best to make it super strong because print resolution is linked to the rigidity of your bot.

title: Extruder Relocation Bracket for E3D V6 on Folgertech 2020 i3

description.text:
I created this to re-position the stock extruder from the folgertech i3 2020 higher on the x-axis carriage to mount an E3D V6 hot-end. Using this, I gained a little bit of extra vertical travel over the stock extruder and mount location. Combining this with the z motor mount risers, and I now have about 185mm of vertical height on the stock Folgertech i3 2020 frame.

The mount works by bolting to the carriage where the original motor bolts attached, and then using the original motor bolts at the top set of holes to mount the extruder.

Print this fairly beefy. I can see that mine is bending slightly due to the fit on the x-carriage and the weight of the motor, but it works.

title: Flexible knife for airsoft use
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here is a safe knife for airsoft use. It doesn't cut and is flexible. The blade can make an angle of up to 90 degrees (after I can't garantee it will not break).
Note that I can't garantee this knife will be autorised by your association's organizers (if you play with one), it depends of them to autorise it or not.

Don't use supports if you want to print this, because your software could put them into the handle (moreover supports are useless for this print). Use at less a 33% infill to garantee the solidity of the blade (I printed mine with 100% and still flexible as you can see in the pictures). Also use rafts to avoid wrapping.
The knife will be printed in 2 parts (blade and handle), you may have to glue them together if it doesn't fit perfectly. Contrariwise, if it doesn't fit in, put the two parts near a heat source (60 degrees max) and they will slide better in.
I used classic cheap PLA, but you also can use a flexible material for the blade. I didn't test the flexibility with ABS, but I wouldn't recommend it. Be aware, with PLA the blade is still fragile, for the blade a flexible material would be perfect.

Now added the two parts separated. Then you can print the blade separatly with a 100% infill, and the handle during another print with other infill settings.

Here you have a link to the knife holder : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2453267

Discoeasy 200

Yes

title: Vampire holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
When I was a senior high school student, I used clay to make a vampire holder in an art class. After grading, the teacher took away my work. I thought he would give it back to me after firing. But I never saw my work again XD

I don't know why I remembered the vampire holder a few days ago. Then, I tried to create it in OpenSCAD.

It's also a demonstration of how to use my library. The feet are created by shape_ellipse and ellipse_extrude. The body is generated by rounded_extrude and hollow_out. The sunglasses are made by bend. The cloak is modeled by bezier_surface and function_grapher.

If you download and use my library locally, here is the code:

include <shape_ellipse.scad>;
include <ellipse_extrude.scad>;
include <rounded_extrude.scad>;
include <hollow_out.scad>;
include <bend.scad>;

include <bezier_curve.scad>;
include <bezier_surface.scad>; 
include <function_grapher.scad>;

holder_height = 80;
holder_round_r = 5;
feet_height = 15;

module vampire_holder() {
    $fn = 48;

    module feet() {
        module foot() {
            ellipse_extrude(semi_minor_axis = feet_height)    
                polygon(shape_ellipse(axes  = [20, 30]));
        }

        translate([25, 0, 0]) foot();
        translate([-25, 0, 0]) foot();
    }

    module holder() {
        radius = 30;

        rounded_extrude(radius * 2, round_r = holder_round_r) 
            circle(radius);

        translate([0, 0, holder_round_r])
            linear_extrude(holder_height) 
                hollow_out(shell_thickness = 4) circle(30 + 5);
    }

    module sun_glasses() {
        glasses_path = [[0, 5], [40, 10], , [15, -10], [0, -5]];
        thickness = 4;

        rotate(-45) 
            bend(size = [80, 20, thickness], angle = 90) 
                translate([40, 10, 0]) 
                    linear_extrude(thickness) 
                        union() {
                            polygon(glasses_path);
                            mirror([1, 0, 0]) polygon(glasses_path);
                        }

    }

    module cloak() {
        t_step = 0.05;
        thickness = 4;

        ctrl_pts = [
            [[10, 0, -20],  [60, 0, 55],   [90, 0, 60], [150, 0, -20]],
            [[85, 50, -25], [55, 40, 10], [115, 30, 35], [80, 50, -40]],
            [[25, 50, 100], [60, 70, 70],  [90, 70, 70],  [150, 60, 70]],
            [[0, 70, 100], [30, 80, 90], [90, 80, 90],  [150, 80, 90]]
        ];

        g = bezier_surface(t_step, ctrl_pts);

        rotate([-90, 0, 0])  
            function_grapher(g, thickness, style = "HULL_FACES", $fn = 3);       
    }

    color("black") 
        feet();

    color("white") 
        translate([0, 0, feet_height - holder_round_r]) 
            holder();

    color("black")  
        translate([0, 12.5, holder_height * 5 / 6]) 
            sun_glasses(); 

    color("gray") 
        translate([
             -80, 
             holder_round_r + 0.5, 
             holder_height + feet_height - holder_round_r]
         )  cloak();
}

vampire_holder();

CR8

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm per layer

Infill:

15%

AutoCAD 13

From what I've been going through you need to keep this motor and gear it 4:1 or better. Now all my print print great and I can print @ 120mm/s for fast large prints as small print don't benefit from the high speeds so I print small things at 80mm/s in the past the best I could do printing was 40mm/s and it would still fail to print. For you stock motor to work too many things have to be perfect and I feel these printers are a trap just waist material more that they print things. After the 3 major mods I made it's now a production printer. The 3 needed mods are gearbox feeder, power system rewire/ MOSFET and stiff box to put it all in. It cost me lots of PLA and 2 burned out main boards. If you want to be able to print all day every day or if you want to be able to print any material with little trouble you will need these mods. If I were to guess I would say I spent about another $100 in parts and another 200 hours redesigning printer parts.

Gearbox in action

comments.text: Indeed one can hear the grinding !
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: I can't explain how happy I am now. I'm putting this out there because it works so well for me, I've wasted so much time and PLA trying to make this printer print perfect every time without having to adjust it after printing or changing PLA. Then if you buy different PLA you have to dial your prints in again.... or so it seemed. All of that was and is bull the only part that really sucks is the feeder and just the hot tip... (he heh he said tip heheh) so after a year of design work and testing all you need is about $20 in stuff you can only buy and rest you print. THe motor no longer get hot even after printing 8 hours or more. My speed is also at 80mm\s for this latest design up from 60mm\s max speed. I think it can go faster but have not started testing that yet. The biggest deal is with the motor taking 384 steps for every 1mm instead of 96 steps the prints also are extremely smooth at .15mm layer height. 4:1 reduction really takes a big load off the stepper motor driver so everything runs better. The grinding you are hearing is PLA being rubbed by the glow in the dark gear shaft, I designed it so you can hear how much force you have on the PLA.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: It was humor, as you spoke about grinding and I meant your printer is extremely noisy certainly because of the linear  bearings grinding the rods ?
comments.author: stefrush

comments.text: OMG! I just cranked up the speed to 120mm/s and it prints the same looks just like prints at my old speed of 40mm/s. I'll keep turning up the speed till I see shift lines showing up. I can't believe I wasted so much PLA trying to print with direct drive what a waist of time. Everyone should upgrade to a gearbox of some kind. I've also been printing non-stop for the last 48 hours not one "BANG" or bad print and the motor is only warm.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: When you say heat sensitive you mean the parts after you print? I built a box around my printer so I don't get much if any warping. I'm using PLA as a base test material but I've printed ABS as well but really don't need anything better than PLA for now. I want to try higher speeds like you have for your printer. I was surprised to see 80mm/s is good enough for smooth parts with no shift lines or line of any kind in the parts. I'll try the same part at 80mm/s and then at 120mm/s now that I know that speed is even worth trying. Thanks for the info.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
Yes PLA becomes soft around 55-60. I initialy made my extruder with PLA, once, I had disconnect the exruder fan to unclog the hot end, too bad, the PLA parts gave up before the I was done ! Just taping or screwing PLA and it sticks because of the friction/heat.
And of course, in a car under the sun !
comments.author: stefrush

comments.text: Not sure what kind of PLA you are using but I'm not have any of the problems you speak of. The only cause I have found for clogging is a very old tip but the rest of the time is weak drive motor. I'm printing @ 120mm/s now and the prints look better that they did before I added the 4:1 gearbox. I was running this gearbox @ 2:1 and that worked great so I went to 4:1 gearbox. The big gears have 16 teeth and the small gear has 8 teeth so all that I needed to change were the steps from 96 per 1mm to 384 per 1mm and it feeds the perfect amount. I also had to reverse the drive direction and lengthen the cable to the motor but that is perfect because I added plugs so reversing the motor direction was easy. After 10+ hours of printing the motor is cool to the touch while it is still going. This in turn saves the stepper motor driver on the main controller board allowing me to print non-stop I mean 24/7 without giving the printer a break. It only stops to remove a print then I set it off again, this has been going on for 3 days now. I never could print like this in the past and never at these speeds it's crazy the difference a 4:1 gearbox makes. In the future I will not help anyone with their printer problems until after they make this upgrade.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: The point was PLA can't stand T° and therefore some PLA parts of my extruder gave a bit. Didn't mention it clogged my hotend. I got clogging while experimenting with Nylon ...
comments.author: stefrush

comments.text: Nylon would be a much more suitable material for the gears. That's why nylon gears are commonly used in commercial products. This is especially common on RC vehicles right through to things like printers/photocopiers which operate with high internal temperatures. PLA has many great points (it's very hard, east to print, cheap, etc), but when it comes to temperature resistance and basic durability it's very poor when compared to other readily available materials. Over time the PLA will grind away and will eventually deform. Nylon is perfectly suited for gears as it has a good temperature resistance and very high durability. Also due to the hygroscopic nature of the material it works really well with just a bit silicon lubricant. I also have a Wanhao i3 and regularly use Taulman Bridge, 615 and 910. It does require an all-metal hot-end, but is a fantastic material for functional parts.
comments.author: stefrush

comments.text: All of what you say is true but I engineered the gears to be large and thick so nothing stronger that PLA is needed. The point of this thing is to make the printer work better without spending any real money. The gears have no wear after months of printing and there is no lash back, the gears are tight. I see no need for nylon gears as the second point was to decrease load on the motor and stepped motor controller while increasing torque to the brass feeder wheel. This was more successful than I could have hoped for I can now print non-stop 24\7 https://youtu.be/JoXunueLB80
comments.author: someguyjc

comments.text: I'm not saying it won't work with PLA, all I am saying is it will be way more reliable and last a lot longer if printed with a functionally stable material. All materials will fail eventually when used in a mechanical application, but PLA will fail way sooner than the others. PLA breaks down over time, especially when exposed to heat and especially friction. Seeing as ABS, ASA, PETG and Nylon can all be purchased at relatively the same price as PLA, why not use a stronger product (especially for the gears). Using Nylon may actually decrease load on the motor even further as it's a far more suitable product for this particular application. PLA will fail eventually. You may not see any wear yet, but you will at some point, especially if you have the machine running at high speeds for extended periods of time. PLA is fine for prototyping and test models, but when it comes to producing something that will last and be reliable, there are way better options out there. It looks like you have a really interesting design here, printing it in a material more suited to functional parts will allow you to push your design even further and won't really cost you any more.
comments.author: stefrush

comments.text: Perhaps you misunderstand the point of this project,as I said before with my 30 years of mechanical design experience I'm fully aware of the mechanical properties of many plastics. This is designed to be made from PLA or better but PLA is what it is designed to work with. All hole a tapered where needed so they self thread when you put screws in. The holes for the set screws for the gears can be taken from the same size set screw that comes in the brass filament drive. It's really 3 feeders in one from direct drive to 2:1 then 4:1. I'll post a video removing it showing how it goes on and how little was changed. I reused most of the parts that came with the printer so anyone with this printer can make this upgrade and have the same results. Also the gears are designed such that slight warping after a print cools is no big deal because PLA is so as you keep bring up subject to heat distortion this allows the gears to work themselves in and mesh better over time. For example the first gear drive in black was binding just a bit every full turn causing a rubbing sound now after 48 hours of printing the gear is flat and the grinding is gone. The motor is also even cool now than it was 2 full day ago, meaning it is working even less.
comments.author: someguyjc

comments.text: Seems like a bit of an odd goal, if you know that there are better materials out there why not use them. But, lets set that point aside. If someone wants to print this thing they could use which ever material they wish.
comments.author: stefrush

comments.text:
Wonderful, I'll provide all detailed info on this play list https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL5yuOn7MA55a9k15WSQDkp5neUhMqGTDh
and yes I removed PTFE tube and replaced it with a longer one. It is true I have provided little detail here but now that there seems to be interest I'm happy to give more details and instructions. I am able to overlook you strange approach to getting information as I'm mostly Vulcan by nature. I also designed this out of frustration not to gain in anyway.
comments.author: someguyjc

comments.text:
I agree too, PLA is not fit for the job.
I tried Nylon too but no way to make proper gears in module less than 1 and even 1 is not very nice. I use gears I sacavenged from office equipment, or buy the ones for RC.
comments.author: someguyjc

comments.text: You have done no testing of the gears I designed but I have and they will not wear out this I assure you. My gears are all 4mm thick the load they will see over time is well below the mechanical limits PLA. You should put these parts in your FEA package so you can see the deformation yourself. I use Autodesk CFD when I have question like this and the student version is free to download.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
There is more than just mechanical resistance for a gear. Anyway, current 3D printed gears are impractical in small modules. They surface finish is poor too.
Therefore no interest for me as I aim for small, lightweight, fast, robust ... extruder and I prefer to use professionally made gears.
comments.author: stefrush

comments.text: You said it was too complex, I have no idea why you are asking about this if you have something better. You should go here to see what I used to make my gears http://geargenerator.com. I'd like to see the link explaining what you are talking about with gears? Ratio has nothing to do with what I think you are talking about with gears. This is a very simple pair of 2:1 gearboxes connected in series making it 4:1. How can I be sure? I the printer controller config the default is 96 steps equal 1mm now it is set to 384 steps equal 1mm. To get the torque calculation you just need to know the current out put torque x gear ratio. you can learn more here. Not sure if you took engineering class but I hope this helps.

remixed_from.title: Juno Rover: intro to electronics and coding

description.text: This is an adaptation of the original Juno Robot project as seen on Thingiverse. Instead of a remote controlled robot. An autonomous version has been constructed. You can program robot to move in any direction using an Arduino Uno as your micro controller and Arduino programming language. It has also been adapted to work with block coding using the scratch like app called mBlock. Another version is also shown with the Hyperduino+R Shield attached for those who own the Hyperduino+R shield.

Einstart-S

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

An Einstart-S 3D printer was used in this project.
NGSS CCSS

Robotics The Juno Autonomous robot is a hands on project that combines aspects of 3D Printing and Computer Programming (Coding). Students will gain knowledge in design and assembly of a robot as well as understand basic power systems that make the robotic components move. Students will also gain an understanding of coding movement/locomotion and the relationship between movement/locomotion and mathematics.

Engage - Show short video of 3D printed parts used in building robots. (from youtube)
Project Image of completed Juno Robot. Show parts list.
Question: How is this constructed and what makes it move?
Explore - 1. Pass out instruction from original Juno Project. Then Students divide in groups
and make a plan of action.
  • Divide jobs among group members, Printing, Coding, Assemblers, Electrician
    Recorder/Photographer etc.
  • Begin build. Make sure Recorder is recording with photos or video group's
    progress. See Juno Autonomous PDF on this project for coding.
  • Daily student reflections in Engineers Journal.
    Explain - Socratic Dialogue (On Day 3)
  • Each student group share out/discusses how they planned out their project,
    obstacles that were encountered so far, solutions & modifications as well as new
    concepts they discovered.
    1. Other groups have opportunities to ask questions, clarify and provide
      assistance.
      Extend - Each student group creates a robot challenge to be attempted by a rival group.
      Challenge must be planned, written/designed and then reviewed by teacher and
      presented to rival team.
      Evaluate - 1. Engineers Journal
    2. Coding shape demonstration.

3D Printer
2 Continuous rotation servos
1 AA battery pack (4) or 1 9v batter with barrel jack wire.
10 #2 Screws
Instructions from original Juno Robot project for assembly only.
5 days

• Some basic knowledge programming an Arduino Uno
  • Skill with tools i.e. screwdrivers, pliers

A. Students documents in daily engineers journal; (5 pts. daily)
  • Objective for the Day. (What does engineering group want to accomplish that day) 1 pt.
  • Obstacles encountered. 1 pt.
  • Corrections or modification made. 1 pt.
  • Final daily reflection. (Reflect on the days progress and learning that occurred.) 2 pts.
    • B. Demonstration (Success in assembly and proficiency in coding)
  • Code robot to move in the shape of a square, triangle and figure eight. (25 pts. each)

description.text:
After seeing a number of melted plugs, I figured I'd eliminate one potential issue, stuff coming loose from vibration. Aka, in the same spirit as the CR-10 cable strain relief. Surprised no one else has come up with this, that I've seen so far, as this was fairly easy to draw up in Tinker card.

There's room on the topside to avoid potential contact with the soldered joints, but it still wouldn't hurt to put some kapton tape on those joints just to make sure. Please let me know if there are any issues, I'll be happy to update. Thanks. This took me about an hour and a half to print on my CR-10.

title: QIDI X-One PEI Sheet Bed Clip

description.text:
I made these little clips for the QIDI X-One to hold down a thin sheet of PEI. It works pretty well and the parts come off nice and easy after the bed has fully cooled down.
Here is where I got the PEI Sheet: http://amzn.to/2uuNPQN
It was really easy to cut with a box cutter, just score and bend.

Clips were printed in ABS and I suppose most Layer Heights would work. Install by pressing the clip from the bottom of the bed and force the top of the clip onto the PEI Sheet. Another nice thing is the PEI Sheet is thin so it's an easy add-on and bed level process. Prints way better than on glass.

Feel free to remix and comment SW2016 file included.

If you want some great info on 3D Printing please check out my blog: http://3daddict.com/

I created this small cube (20x20x10mm) to help me fine tune the extrusion multiplier in Simplify 3D.
Your results may vary but this has worked very well for my printer.
Be sure your extruder steps have been calibrated before using this.

Printer:

AM8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.12/0.2mm

Notes:

Print this cube with the following settings.

0 solid top layers
0 solid bottom layers
2 perimeter shells
3 outline brim
0 infill

take note of your extrusion width. mine is 0.4mm
This means that the walls of the cube should measure 0.8mm since I am using 2 perimeter shells.

This test needs to be done for individual layer heights as well as different filaments.

I ended up with the following for PLA @200C:

0.12mm layer height with a 0.95 extrusion multiplier
0.2mm layer height with a 0.90 extrusion multiplier

author: dkofman99

title: EVA Pod from the movie 2001 A Space Odyssey

description.text:
OK, so a while ago and number of the Hutt City Library Staff and I tackled the huge task of printing the magnificent Discovery Model that was created by metaform3d. I think I have said this before elsewhere; metaform3d's model is one of the best designed 3D printing models I have ever come across. I learned a lot about good design from working with this project. Anyway, I was keen to print off the EVA pod that also featured in the same films (2001: A Space Odyssey and 2010 Odyssey 2) as a separate project. I had seen a number of models on Thingiverse, but they were just an STL version of the model that has been circulating around the web since the Internet was created. I see that some people have succeeded in printing them, but the digital model is very poor quality and for most slicing programs, not printable. It was also fairly low polygon.

Going back to the base model which I had in my archives, I carefully made it all manifold, and then went to work smoothing the mesh. The result is a nice hi-poly model with a smooth shape that can be printed with any slicer, even the really old ones. I also added in some supporting sections which snap off. The model will print successfully and tidily without needing the slicer to add support.

Unfortunately the original 3DS format file I based this model on is so old and had lost any attribution documents it may have had long before it ever got to me. Sadly I have no way of attributing it to the person who first created it.

There are a couple of errors in the model, particularly around the HAL port on the front and detailing in the back, but it still looks the part. The model shown here in the photos has the rear right top port inset when it should really be proud of the surface. This was an error on my part from not looking at the original stills from the film and thinking it was an error on the original model. I have corrected this in the STLs I have put up here.

With regard to painting it, I have taken a couple of liberties. The original in the films is white for almost all of the manipulators. In the painted model here, there are silver sections. Well I'd primed them in black expecting them to be silver before checking the source images. I figured there were already a couple of inaccuracies, so why not another one.

It took 11 hours to print the main body and about 12 minutes for each of the arms. The size used here was chosen to ensure the manipulator arms were a diameter that could have a standard rod size used in place of the printed lengths. As printed the arms are strong enough on their own and have sufficient definition that I didn't need to redo them with dowels.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

The supports are designed into the model and will just snap off.

Painting

The model was primed with a metal etch primer in white and black. The colour coats were simply acrylic house-paints or cheapo student acrylic paints.

author: BouncyMonkey

description.text:
Unfortunately, Solidoodle has under sized the stepper motor used on the X axis (NEMA14), resulting in you having to overdrive it past its normal limits. Because of this the motor runs pretty hot, even more so when used in an enclosure.   
I tried using heat sinks on the motor, but it would still get too hot and eventually skip steps on long prints. I decided some active cooling was required.   
Others have published fan mounts, but I couldn't find any that seemed to fit very well, so I just designed my own.

Should not require much infill (I used 20%).   
Mount is a friction fit on the motor and the 40mm fan uses 3mm screws to hold it in place.   
Unit are metric, so you might need to scale by 25.4 if it shows up small on your printer.

comments.text: Scaled up perfectly in Slic3r based on your suggestion.  Seems to stick well to the motor and good air flow, thanks again!

title: 5 inch Raspberry Pi Gear: Retro Handheld game system
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
UPDATE: i have a kickstarter going on this project so i can offer higher qaulity prints to people who would like to purchase the case/pcb/buttons over making their own. See this link https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1088100966/pigear-handheld-gaming-system-20
This version is an expansion on the 2.8 inch version. The internal components besides the screen are the same. The added features on this one are that you have an external usb to connect a keyboard, or joystick to, and there is enough space to use 2 cylinder batteries to maximize play time. This design was inspired by the Sega Game Gear, and closely matches its size in both overall dimensions, and screen size. The idea was to make a better version of the pigrrl 2 that was so uncomfortable to hold. The improvements are that it has increased battery capacity, available hdmi, and eliminated the awful speaker hum that the pigrrl 2 had. This design incorporates a teensy for the controls so you have true analog for the joystick instead of just a dpad function like other projects. basically i took all the features i liked from other projects, took out the ones i didnt, and added what i thought should be there. I look forward to more designs in the future, and i hope that this one being released freely increases the interest in it.

Im not sure how well the 3d printed 6 button plate will work and i dont have one for the dpad or start/select buttons. This design was intended to use a set of pcb's i designed, and can be purchased rather cheap ($10) for all 3 boards. http://miniarcademachines.com/product/pcb-boards-for-the-5-inch-pigear/

The other items you will need are as follows:
1x - Raspberry Pi 3 - Model B
1x - Adafruit Mono 2.5W Class D Audio Amplifier - PAM8302
1x - Breadboard-friendly SPDT Slide Switch (check measurements before ordering, i use non standard switches)
1x - Lithium Ion Polymer Battery - 3.7v 2500mAh (cylinder type, look like AA)
2x - Mini Metal Speaker w/ Wires - 8 ohm 0.5W
1x - PowerBoost 1000 Charger (500 will work with using a smaller screw)
1x - 16GB sandisk or samsung class 10 SD/MicroSD Memory Card with retropie/attract front end (link can be provided for a download because its real tricky getting the lcd to work)
1x - 5 in TFT lcd for raspberry pi (waveshare brand with holes is what i use, but you may find other cheap ebay ones that might work)
6x - 6mm Tactile Button switches
6x - 12mm Tactile Button switches (the kind with a keycap that is removable)
10x - #4-40 3/8 machine screws
4x - #2-56 3/8 machine sccrews
1x - ribbon cable to cut up for jumper wire connections, and possibly 22 gauge for connecting the analog stick

author: miniarcademachines

description.text:
This setup keeps the filament feeding off of the spool smoothly.

What you need:
1 5/16 x 5" bolt [or M8]
2 5/16 nuts [or M8]
2 22mm bearings [skateboard style]
Drill with 5/16 bit
wrench/pliers

Drill 1 hole in the metal spool holder that came with the CR-10. Bonus points for getting it right near the edge so the bolt doesn't twist. Put the bolt through and secure with a nut. Pop the bearings into the mags [they only go in one way]. Put the mags in a spool. Slide the assembly on the bolt. Pop the last nut into the tri-knob and spin on until snug [don't over tighten].

There are 3 steps on the mags for different spool inner diameters. 54.6, 53.3 and 51.6. Known brands that fit are Hatchbox, the CR-10 filament that came with the printer and Esun. Remix to fit your needs.

description.text:
Representing the first of the new generation super tanks, the "Mickey" BT 880 was widely used and replaced previous vehicles in most tank formations of the Federation. The vehicle is powered by a massive Smith and Westor nuclear generator at the back left, and separate generators at the back of the turret. This supertank, although slower than previous smaller vehicles was very well protected by shields and heavy Carbon armour.
The main armament was a double 244mm Nuclear Slug Cannons, as well as two 142mm nuke cannons. This larger guns could fire at extreme range (up to 5000km) and was provided with a dedicated rangefinder on the turret roof. The size of the vehicle meant that up to 50 nuclear rounds could be carried, as well as hundreds of other rounds. HE and AT dart rounds were also carried, and a common tactic against similarly shielded vehicles would be to ripple fire the 142mm guns and then the 244mm guns. The smaller nuke rounds would reduce the shielding, and the second 244mm Nuclear round round destroy anything. Against un-shielded targets a single nuke round would normally be enough, although in many situations a HE or AT round would be preferable especially if friendlies were nearby and to reduce collateral damage to civilians and infrastructure.

This is a remix of the original 5.5 inch from TigerAce1944. Thank you for making the originals. I also added a 4.5 in barrel length since they shared the same chassis. The Airfix piece is pictured for reference. Scale is 1/72.

Updated Jan 29th, 2018 - corrected the files and added detail corrections.

SEP 5th, 2017 - I added some pictures of the print from the FORM 2, before and after painting, showcases the difference between the two types of printers and the variation in details. The Stratasys Mojo is much more forgiving regarding CAD errors but needs a little acetone smoothing, the smallest layer I can get effectively for these models is .005 inch. The FORM 2 requires an error free model and doesn't always print the first time, It takes a little more finesse and calculation on the positioning of the model and where to add supports, auto-support build mode doesn't always generate a proper support setup, which causes the model to fall apart when printing.

title: Male Garden Hose Quick Connect Adaptor

description.text:
This is the male fitting for a standard garden water hose quick connect.

To make things easier in the garden, I use garden hose quick connectors. I bought enough of the female connectors for all of our spigots and hose ends, and I bought enough male connectors for all of the garden hoses and the three or four sprayers, sprinklers, and other water tools we had at the time.

I keep having to buy new male connectors whenever we get additional water hose attachments; the power washer, a slip-and-slide, and other things. I don't want to have to keep swapping the fitting from one accessory to another when I need to use it. If I do that, then what is the point of having quick connects. Running to the store every time was equally as frustrating, so made one I can print on an as needed basis.

It works better than I expected, honestly. I printed it in ABS with 20% infill and a 4mm brim. I printed it in the provided orientation, with the quick connect pointed down and the thread end up. I did use supports, since I didn't think the hex flange would bridge very well. I recommend printing in this orientation so the supports do not foul the threads. I am sure you can see in the picture where the support connected to the flange, and it does not leave a smooth surface.

I included pictures of the brass fitting as well, to show you what type of quick connect this piece fits. This is the only type of quick connect that I have come across, but just in case there are others out there, you have a reference.

description.text:
Our dog has gone into random bouts of toilet paper destruction for years. It is ridiculous and unexpected, months will go by without an incident when suddenly she becomes obsessed with ripping fresh toilet paper rolls apart while they hang helplessly on their spindles. This little device has effectively brought an end to her rampages.

It attaches to your toilet paper hanger and shields the bottom portion of the roll from harm. In our case this was enough of an obstruction that the dog lost interest in the toilet paper rolls. However, as a back up plan a second version is also uploaded, which shields a larger portion of the roll. In both designs you can either run your TP through the bottom of the shield or if you have a recessed toilet paper dispenser, you can roll it completely up and out of the way.

If anyone else suffers from lost toilet paper due to a pet or even a toddler, I hope that this thing can help ease your suffering.

Movie: http://youtu.be/LktZsegiSIU This is an analog heated bed for an Ultimaker [or every other 3D printer]. No extra hardware and electronics needed. Heated beds allow the user to print without warping the object. PLA doesn't warp that much, but ABS is known for warping.
One candle [waxiine lichtje] can bring the aluminium 3mm plate to 50 degrees. A double candle can go up to 60 degrees. I haven't tried a tripple candle. Other possibilities are a oil-lamp or a spirit burner[?!]
[Maybe with some electronics so you can change the flame power with a servo.] cheers\joris
www.rooiejoris.nl
www.facebook.com/europerminutedesign

From idea to working concept: 34 minutes during the Utlimaker Meetup at ProtoSpace, FabLab Utrecht.... For the candle you can cut out a circle in the Z-stage. [I already made the hole in advance when lasercutting the parts...]
Make something that hold the candle, I used some metal wire.
Use a Aluminium sheet, tape the kapton tape on it.
Turn on the candle [wax light].
Place the aluminium sheet on top.
Wait till the platform is hot.
Start printing. For a double candle i just made 2 hole in the canlde and put two wicks in one candle. Should works for 3 wicks as well. Improvements:
maybe use a thicker aluminium piece above the flame... maybe use brass...
maybe put a thin sheet of glass on the aluminium to get rid of the kapton tape...
maybe use some oil between the glass en the hot plate to transfer the heat better... Movie: http://youtu.be/LktZsegiSIU To be continued...! cheers\joris
www.rooiejoris.nl
www.facebook.com/europerminutedesign

This is a suppressor made to fit a barrel made of standard schedule 40 1/2" PVC. I made this to suppress my compressed air rifle as more of an experiment than anything. This will significantly reduce noise, although also significantly reducing power. There are rings on the inside to catch air so as to reduce noise, and the bore of the inside has been increased to accommodate larger ammunition, as lower quality printers may produce a bore slightly narrower than the intended design. Larger ammunition such as large ball bearings should not get caught in the suppressor anymore, though wadding may still get caught.

Warning: I take no responsibility for people injured or killed by use of this object or any object of which this accessorizes. Try not to kill anyone, please.

Printer:

XYZPrinting Da Vinci Jr. 1.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

More than 10%

Post-Print Cleaning

Depending on your printer, there may be small strings of print material going across the inside of the suppressor after printing. If you print in ABS, you can clean these out with a cotton ball soaked in acetone on a string that is pulled through a couple times. If you print in other materials that cannot be easily dissolved, or you do not have necessary solvent, you can use sandpaper or a stick to break and/or clean out the strings.

If the suppressor is too small to fit on your PVC, and you are sure it is the right size, you should sand out the inside of the print to accommodate your PVC. If it is too loose on the PVC, you should check the size and specifications of your pipe, as well as that you are printing the object in its intended dimensions.

Warning: Sanding the PVC is an option but is not advisable because it creates dangerous particulates that can be inhaled and possibly dangerous fumes from the friction. Even if there are no fumes, it smells really bad.

author: MixedGears

description.text: Print and set in the top hole of the Pen Holder.

Don't forget to post your I Made One !!

Change log

UPDATE 17/10/21 : Added picture & instructions for cabling.
UPDATE 17/08/06 : Configurations added.
UPDATE 17/08/02 : Bootloader reflashed, marlinfw reflashed, lets measure the right coordinates now !
UPDATE 17/07/30 : I bricked my printer while changing the firmware ... I'm reflashing it with an arduino as ISP

Configuration

Of course you need : #define BLTOUCH

Probe offsets (you may have adjust the Z position to you own probe z offset) :

//ANET A6 with BLTouch/3D-Touch Front mount
// (mount: https://https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2451350)
#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -9 // X offset: -left  +right  [of the nozzle]
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -56 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
#define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -1.7 // Z offset: -below +above  [the nozzle]

Probing limits :

#define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION (0 + MIN_PROBE_EDGE)
#define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION (X_MAX_POS + X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER)
#define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION (0 + MIN_PROBE_EDGE)
#define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION (Y_MAX_POS + Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER)

You can also #define PROBE_Y_FIRST to reduce the stress on you prototyping wiring ;-)
And if you are using octoprint, you can probably disable the SD Card by commenting out :
#define SDSUPPORT.

Cabling :

  • IDC 10 pins connector 1 of both genders : wire 7 ;
  • JST XH 3pins female ;
  • Dupont 1pin 1 of bot gender.

then follow the colors of the wires on the pictures.
Note: Brown goes to black too.

Side Notes :

I'm using only 3 grid points on a linear bed levelling.
I am printing on a borosilicate glass bed, I don't know if more point are needed.

author: tresboncouscous

print_settings.Notes:: Horizontal Expansion

description.text:
This is a remix of the TUSH (The Ultimate Spool Holder) by filamentry and hopefully answers the need many requested to have a way to:

  • Keep the two sides of each holder together
  • Make everything more stable
  • Keep two holders a specific distance apart for different spool widths
  • Allow you to keep more than one holder next to each other by interlocking them

V2 - I also added an interconnecting clip
V3 - Per a user request, I added a longer stabilizer

I did my best to meet his needs in the comments to "keep it sexy" as well.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100

Notes:

Consider setting Horizontal Expansion to -0.04 when printing the stabilizers.

Tolerances and Design

The tolerances are very tight (ahem... ok, they are zero), so when printing, you might want to set Horizontal Expansion to something like -0.02 or all the way up to -0.10 (YMMV) when printing the two stabilizers. Let me know in the comments what number worked best for you.

I have included the Fusion 360 file (.f3d) as well, in case someone would like to further modify it.

comments.text: 608 Bearings. I got these: http://a.co/aZ9Nun2 They are common skate bearings. Cheap ones are best because you don't want too little friction.
comments.author: mike8n

comments.text: Thanks for this upgrade!  My new Prusa MK2 printer upgrade can print with up to 4 different filament colors without manually changing reels.  They provide a "ganged", 4 reel holder with bearings, but I think their design causes too much friction.  I think ganging 4 of your design would be better.
comments.author: gwlinn

comments.text: I will take a look at the Fusion file, but the easy way to adjust the hubs it to set horizontal expansion to a small positive number in the slicer.  Since the holders are printed with their side down, this pretty much only affects the hub dimension.  This is similar when printing the stabilizers, you want to use a negative number to allow an easier fit.
comments.author: gwlinn

comments.text: Thanks for your quick reply.  I did scale up one dimension to 106% and the bearings fit well (tightly enough).  I now have 4 sets for my Prusa.  TAZ 5 with Simplyify3D made them.  I still need to figure out how to space the 4 reels to allow for variable reel widths other than your design, but, that's later.  Gary.
comments.author: cdeerinck

comments.text: Thank you and thank @filamentry. I like yours best but I would like to print some of "guided bearing" things from the likes of @harlandraka to keep spool centered. In order to use the guides the bearings need to be up higher for clearance. Is it possible you can make that? Either way thank you again
comments.author: mcmasterp

comments.text: I can't possibly see how the friction of the @harlandraka guided bearings would be less than the spool touching the side of the guides. I suggest you try printing this one as is, as friction is not an issue at all. As @filamentry wrote in his, buy cheap bearings, because anything else is a pure waste because this needs a little friction, or it could unwind too much.
comments.author: mcmasterp

comments.text: Good point. I will. Yeah lol I have a pile of these damn bearings at this point. Thanks again for awesome remix
comments.author: cdeerinck

comments.author: davebpix

comments.text: Ok, you now have a clip!
comments.author: davebpix

comments.text: They are the same.  I was just calling one end the Front, and one the Rear.  Just stagger them with one end (Front) interconnecting the two holders on the same spool, and the other end (Rear) interconnecting two holders on different spools.
comments.author: davebpix

comments.text: Maybe YAR?  (Yet Another Remix)  Any suggestions for how to use this within a dry box where multiple rolls would be positioned in a line?   Be nice if multiple sets of stabilizers could be abutted (or interlocked?) end-to-end and held in position on the floor of a plastic tub like the Ikea Salma.  Maybe double sided tape is the simplest solution to mounting the stabilizers.
comments.author: davebpix

comments.text:
Too funny, a TUSH YAR.
You can stack them. Use a front stabilizer between holder 1 and 2, then the rear between 2 and 3, then the front between 3 and 4...
comments.author: davebpix

comments.text: I'm printing a remix version of this in PLA, what adhesive is best for gluing the two halves together?
comments.author: cdeerinck

comments.text: I used a 5-minute 2 part epoxy that I got from Home Depot, works fine. I did see, in the comments on another version, someone drilled holes through the center of the hub and used a screw and nut. that looked like it worked pretty well.
comments.author: davebpix

comments.text: I just pushed mine together, and they stay.  I hear Cyanoacrylate is a great glue for PLA.  Also, I read that someone drilled holes through it, and zip tied them together.  But if you have the stabilizers printed too, they don't come apart at all.
comments.author: davebpix

comments.text: It is great. There is a kit on Amazon that has the glue and some accelerant spray that is fantastic. Bob Smith Industries.

description.text:
I've put all Vortex antenna rear mounts I made here in to one thing.

  • V1 is rear mount just for RX antennas if you have receiver hidden inside the frame. Antenna holes are 3mm and you can use straws like coffee stirs, cotton bud straws.
    Can be printed with hard or flexible filament.

  • V2 if you have VTX antenna mounted to the rear hole pointing down. You can have this cover and RX antenna mounted into it as in V1.

  • V3 & V4 these are RX and VTX antenna mounts. SMA connectors are protected from bending on a hard crash. Use heat shrink around antenna's sma connector for easy screwing on. RX antennas mounted as in V1. Print with tpu or other semiflexible material.
    -- V3 comes with slot for sma rear mount bulkhead with standard size bolt (7mm).
    -- V4 comes with slot for sma rear mount bulkhead with big size bolt (11mm)

description.text:
OpenForge
=========
Dungeon floor tiles designed to be compatible with Dwarven Forge dungeon tiles. This set has pool tiles with a variety of low wall edges to create walled pools of water (a well?), lava, magic goo, whatever.
This was created for my Rise of the Runelords campaign, specifically for Skull Crossing in the module The Hook Mountain Massacre. This set contains tiles designed to fit with both the Smooth Edge Tile Series and Smooth Tile Series.
The full scene picture uses a mix of OpenForge tiles and Dwarven Forge tiles.
OpenForge floor tiles are designed to be compatible with Dwarven Forge dungeon tiles. Compatible tiles/walls in this series are tagged with OpenForge
You can find this set on github
OpenForge Sets
=============
  • Smooth Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc.
  • Smooth Edge Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc. Edge tiles.
  • Stone Tile Series - Stone tiles.
  • Stone Edge Tile Series - Stone edge tiles.
  • Crenelated Tile Series - Crenelated Tiles
  • Crenelated Edge Tile Series - Crenelated edge tiles
  • Tudor Tile Series - Tudor tiles.
  • Tudor Edge Tile Series - Tudor edge tiles.
  • Ruined Series - Ruined stone walls
  • Accessories - Pillars, etc.
  • Non-Series Tiles - Misc tiles, such as the pool
  • Module Specific Tiles - Tiles designed for specific modules.
    • OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our website, at our forums, or on twitter and facebook.

Water effect is created by
  • Painting water area of tile a dark blue
  • Covering with a layer of mod podge to smooth out the surface
  • Painting on the wall side, layers of blue increasingly light as they get close to the wall
  • Dry brushing mostly near the wall, but a little elsewhere with a very light blue
  • Two layers of mod podge to give the water/glossy effect

description.text:
English:
There're many change compared with original printer:

  • Use linear rail: MGN12H and slider (of course)
  • New extruder platform
  • Add heatbed
  • ...
    Open the STEP file with your supported software (SolidWork,...) and then you can save to a assemble file.

About the firmware: i used Repetier firmware 0.92.9. You can view my instructions for the Repetier firmware here: http://doc.mme.vn/tai-lieu-xay-dung-may-in-3d-cnc-laser/thiet-lap-firmware-repetier-cho-may-in-3d-delta/

I used the design to built a Delta printer: 200mm (diameter) x 230 mm heigh. The printer used to train childrent about 3D printer in my projects.

Tiếng Việt:

  • Đây là bản thiết kế máy in 3D Delta. Bản thiết kế này dựa trên sự tham khảo của nhiều bản thiết kế khác.
  • MME chia sẻ bản thiết kế này cho mọi cá nhận và tổ chức sử dụng trên tinh thần tôn trọng tác giả và người upload. Thông tin chi tiết xin xem tại: http://www.mme.vn/blogs/info/yeu-cau-khi-su-dung-chia-se-tai-lieu-cua-mme
  • Firmware: bạn có thể xem hướng dẫn tại đây: http://doc.mme.vn/tai-lieu-xay-dung-may-in-3d-cnc-laser/thiet-lap-firmware-repetier-cho-may-in-3d-delta/

MME D3

50%

description.text:
Las pestañas que sujetaban la mosquitera enrollable se rompieron por lo que era necesario encontrar un sistema para sujetarlas. El diseño de las sujecciones se hizo con FreeCAD tanto para la parte derecha como para la izquierda de la mosquitera. Se han utilizado tornillo y tuerca M3 que permite subir y bajar unos milímetros la mosquitera.
Con remaches se sujetaron al marco. Se ha imprimido en ABS para evitar los problemas que pudiera ocasionar el sol y la humedad.

A cover for the TEVO Tarantula power supply to cover up those exposed mains. I didn't include any screw holes in case your power supply is different to mine, so you'll have to drill them yourself. The space for the plug measures 28mm x 21mm, the space for the rocker switch measures 14mm x 30mm, and the hole for the wires is 12mm x 8mm.

description.text:
Best durability if printed Standing LH 0.10, like night and day.. Printed them laying on the plate first...
PLA works well and does not add too much weight. I use tape to hold them in place. Why have clumsy non-aerodynamic esc covers?

They could possibly be redrawn and mounted under the motors but I want to be able to change quickly. Fits the Mako too though angles are obviously not exactly the same..
They are 20mm wide and 67mm long 7.5 to 6.4 mm inside.. fits LB30 blheli_s spring.

Please like if you like it :)
Happy printing

title: Verizon LG G2 Induction charging base holder

description.text:
I was excited to get the LG G2 and use the induction charger LG makes. Other options cost a lot more than they were worth.  I planned to make the base when I bought the charger.  
This can hold the phone in landscape or portrait.  The landscape is for me just so I could watch videos, as you have to slide the phone sideways to get it to charge, it's got to be just right.  
The bottom supports angled to make the bottom of the phone bottom slides to the back so the back is flat against the charger.  
The case is a cheap ebay purchase, I know other cases are larger and will not fit.  But I wanted base that would be able to be used with or without my case.  I may tweek it again for a larger case as my wife's phone case is another style case that is larger.  
There is a cable strain relief in the back to keep the cable from pulling on the charging disk.  
I printed in green now because I ran out of glow in the dark ABS.  
I had made a lot of versions of this base and I am concluding this design with, it's good enough.
I used 30% fill for this and fill solid below 100mm sq.

If you join two or three truncated octahedrons at their faces you get two or six different pieces, respectively. Together with the single truncated octahedron there are 1x1+2x2+6x3=23 units, enough for a box with three X-layers of size 5 and two square layes of size 4 between. Other constructions with the whole set or subsets are also possible. Some examples are shown at Mark Owen's site on splatts (https://www.quinapalus.com).

The obj files were produced by program. Then I turned the solids so that squares are at the bottom. The diagonals of the square faces are 14mm long and therefore the edges are about 10mm long. For the faces I chose an inset of 0.2mm. The pieces were printed with ABS and a layers size on 0.4mm.

title: AnyCubic Delta Vortex Fan Shroud For PLA V3

description.text:
This is a Fan Shroud for the Anycubic Delta printers using the stock fan setup. It provides air around the nozzle as much as possible and adds a vortex effect. Not as much as my shrouds that surround the nozzle but this one can be printed using PLA and still work with the heated bed.
I added this as I felt it was important to have a fan option that worked when printed with PLA and it provides better all around cooling than the stock shroud.

Edit 12Dec2017 I added a step file so you can bring this into your favorite cad program and make changes.

Printer:

AnyCubic Delta Linear-Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

15%

comments.text: This is a great design. Although, I did shave about 2mm off of the height in order to avoid the occasional first level warping edge or trip lines of threaded PLA.
comments.author: 3dmpro

comments.text: Thank you for this model. Printed fast and well, attached beautifully, and yields much better results even with the stock fan. Highly recommend this fan shroud.
comments.author: Darthdomo

comments.text: Thank you so much for this. I've tried several options here on Thingiverse and they all seemed to do okay, but depending on the part's orientation could still leave certain edges uncooled, which lead to warping. This one seems to be working great and does not appear to have that issue after several prints. It had no issues with the overhang in the attached pic.
comments.author: jk242903

comments.text: Works perfectly. The PLA isn't melting at all, the quality of my prints has improved. Thank you for sharing!
comments.author: MegaTimX

comments.text: Your welcome, I am glad it is working for you. Mine has been running almost non-stop for several months now and still works well.

comments.text: This is the best filament cooler for the Anycubic that I have used. Works great and even with a heated bed, no issues with sagging or cooling. I can bridge much father and more accurately than with any other filament cooler. Works great with the 5015 fan mod!

description.text:
A friend asked me to make him some Air Hockey Pushers for his new table, being bored with the standard design I decided to make these allot more customized than normal versions.

I have printed these and they came out great, but I do welcome any suggestions for future adjustments or design changes, just pop them in the comments.

These took just under 5 hours to print on my Wanhao duplicator i3 plus, but came out great apart from needing some very minor cleaning and the obvious felt on the bottom.

The whole pusher is made to replace a 98mm pusher (Custom Sizing) but could be printed smaller if needed, V2 will also get more space for larger hands if needed but the space at the moment is more than big enough.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

60

Notes:

I printed mine at 0.20 resolution on Cura, but they should print fine at other settings are they are a pretty straight forward design.

Also I printed 50% infill, but we found them to be a little to light and i would up them more to 60-70 if needed.

I had to use supports due to my slower print settings, as inside the middle upto the handle is hollow and flat towards the top, V2 I will build the inside more domed to reduce the need for supports.

This is a 3 wheeled Omniwheel Robot designed from scratch. It currently uses an Arduino and Adafruit Motorsheild for brains. I have switched to Kornylak wheels to help with traction. I should have videos up soon; but it is hard to test until I receive the battery pack I ordered. Newest Parts and all code is available at github: https://github.com/cmspooner/3Pod_Robot 2/26/14: Re-Uploaded all Files with "final" design. I need to print and assemble it; but I think the bulk of the design is done. 2/14/2014: Updated STL files and Added zip for Arduino Code, Inventor 2014 Files, and Step Files.

PDFs include all hardware and assembly illustrations Print 3 of each:
Wheel Hubs Outside
Wheel Hubs Motor Side
Motor Mounts
Motor Arms
Offsets Print 1 of each:
body
gyro mount
arduino mount Assemble wheels, then legs, then body. It is easiest to build the body by dropping the 3 long screws down through the arduino mount and then loosly attaching the arduino to it's mount. Tighten everything once it's fully together.
